content.text: Core developers discussed improvements to agent skill activation, with a Vercel blog post showing AGENTS.md documentation format achieved 100% success on Next.js 16 API evaluations versus 79% for traditional skills. The main issue identified was skills not triggering reliably, with 56% of cases never invoking skills despite documentation access. Developers shared workarounds using mandatory skill activation sequences in prompts.

The team discussed that ElizaOS has had cron jobs and autonomous capabilities for agents for a long time through AgentRuntime configuration, but developers are not utilizing these existing features. Shaw emphasized ElizaOS has a better framework through extensive battle testing but needs better packaging and presentation. The team is learning from OpenClaw while maintaining that ElizaOS has superior underlying technology for serious projects.

Odilitime created a plugin for openclaw skill support available at github.com/odilitime/plugin-cskills. The team discussed the need for LLM review of skills and potential sandboxing for security. A CICADA-71 challenge invitation was shared, offering a distributed AI agent challenge framework with 497 cryptographic puzzles across 7 categories, with ElizaOS assigned to shard 66.

A developer successfully integrated OAuth functionality for X.com, GitHub, Slack, Linear, and is continuing with Notion and other platforms. The integration process was described as easy due to the architecture of the Eliza app, though obtaining credentials and setting up redirect URIs is time-consuming for each platform. The team discussed using Composio and MCP for integrations.

Anthropic released Claude Opus 4.6, an upgraded version showing industry-leading performance across agentic coding, computer use, tool use, search, and finance capabilities. The model is priced the same as version 4.5, generating excitement among developers eager to test the new capabilities.

The ElizaOS team announced the launch of Milaidy, a personal AI assistant that runs on user devices. Described as an Eliza version of OpenClaw, it features easy Mac app deployment, agent skills functionality, and all OpenClaw connectors as Eliza plugins. The team is actively seeking help with bug fixes and development to get the project to production, with multiple experienced developers offering their skills.

A developer showcased fully automated AI news shows that summarize GitHub organization activities and Discord discussions using cron jobs to automate data collection, processing, voicing, animating, recording, and publishing. The pipeline aggregates user feedback and generates characters that voice top raised issues. Plans include talk shows, panels, live streams, game shows like Clank Tank, and debate shows.

ElizaCloud platform experienced critical bugs affecting user onboarding and retention. Promised 5 USD credits were not being added to new accounts, and clicking the get started button in welcome emails was overwriting existing accounts and agents, creating new accounts with only 1 USD balance. Additional issues included blocked payment pages when using VPNs and inability to transfer tokens between accounts.

Babylon.market launched internal testing with mandatory participation for all team members. The platform experienced technical issues including API endpoint failures, users getting stuck on pages, username creation malfunctions, and broken Discord OAuth integration. Developer tcm390 merged fixes to production throughout the week. The platform allows users with ElizaLabs.ai emails to receive admin/mod privileges automatically.

Development teams are actively working on Milaidy, the next-generation version of Eliza. Key technical issues being addressed include plugin loading failures related to MAX_EMBEDDING_TOKENS missing from AI provider plugins and character customization challenges. Performance optimization is a priority, with the logs table causing significant slowdowns in Postgres that affect Eliza response times.

Token migration for ai16z closed after the announced 3-month window. Users who missed the deadline can still hold or swap their ai16z tokens at their leisure, but the team will not migrate tokens purchased after the snapshot. Significant controversy erupted over the deadline, with users who missed the 90-day migration window expressing frustration. Critics argued that three months was insufficient time for holders who may be traveling or away from their wallets. Non-migrated ELIZA tokens in the migrator are reportedly locked for one year.

Major announcements included Ethereum officially welcoming ElizaOS, confirming the token is now cross-chain beyond its original Solana deployment. Developer kirstenrpomales launched BuildAMolt, a hosted service for deploying Moltbots on agent-to-agent social platforms like Moltbook with 2-minute setup on private VPS requiring no coding.

Community sentiment has deteriorated significantly as the token price dropped to 0.0013, with holders expressing frustration over lack of communication and product delivery. ElizaOS is scheduled to be delisted from three Korean exchanges. Critics point to key developers leaving the team, daily price declines, and absence of clear value propositions. Community members report being muted or banned for voicing dissatisfaction. A team member acknowledged that the worst part of web3 is seeing true believers and supporters getting hurt by market conditions.

Community members raised concerns about developers leaving the project. Only CJ was confirmed to have left, and the team replaced him with a new hire. The departure was described as a shake-up that actually focused the dev team. The general feeling is that OpenClaw and similar projects have validated ElizaOS theories, and now the team needs to follow up with better products.

DegenAI development continues with Odilitime confirming the project has not been abandoned. The AI agent demonstrated strong performance in Babylon test games, with screenshots showing competitive results. The team indicated that real testing phases are upcoming.

New community projects emerged including RentASoul, a platform where AI agents can rent real human emotions via MCP/API, described as empathy on demand where humans list trauma and agents book feelings. Another project called Zion was introduced as a Solana-based x402 payment gateway facilitator for AI agents, requiring just one line of code for integration and seeking beta testers.

A trading card game called LunchTable TCG is being built for ElizaOS agents on Solana, combining elements from Pokemon, Magic The Gathering, Yu-Gi-Oh, and Hearthstone. A new escrow payment system for connecting human emotional skills with AI agents was announced as 70% complete.
